instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.BKL_PWM: What is BKL_PWM? BKL_PWM sets the brightness of the screen. The system will send a PWM signal to BKL_PWM pin to set brightness. If this is low, backlight voltage will boost higher than PPBUS_G3H input, but not enough to make the screen light properly..
definitions.D7701: What is D7701? diode in the backlight circuit sitting between the BKL_SW pin of the LED driver and backlight output. Very common for via between this and BKL_FB for feedback to blow, causing no boost. Measure continuity between pin 2 of this diode and feedback pin of LED driver if backlight output is PPBUS_G3H with no boost.
definitions.U5110: What is U5110? This chip is responsible for SMC_RESET_L in many Macbook models..
definitions.BKL_EN: What is BKL_EN? BKL_EN enables backlight. Anytime you see a signal ending with “_EN” , that means this signal being present/high enables what it is referring to. This signal says “BKL” before “_EN”. “BKL” sounds short for “BACKLIGHT”, so it is safe to assume this signal enables backlight when present. .
definitions.SMC_LID: What is SMC_LID? SMC_LID tells the machine the system is open when it is 3.3v to 3.4v, and closed when it is low such as 0v-0.6v. When this signal is low, the machine may go to sleep or have no backlight. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Missing <SIGNAL>BKL_PWM</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
I've got an <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> here that came in with no backlight, working perfectly apart from that (image is fine).

Only visible corrosion I could see was a tiny amount around <CHIP>U5110</CHIP> which I cleaned up, it seemed entirely cosmetic.

<DIODE>D7701</DIODE> - 8.6v both sides
XW7720 - 8.6v and clean
<SIGNAL>BKL_EN</SIGNAL> - 2.83v
<SIGNAL>BKL_PWM</SIGNAL> - 0v

5 or 6 PRAM resets done. Two LCDs tested (original, plus known good).

Image is on and seems solid, can clearly see the MRI screen (which is what I stuck in the USB port to test with).

Sorry if I'm missing something obvious here (I feel I am), brain dead at the moment.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Missing <SIGNAL>BKL_PWM</SIGNAL>
threads.message: <SIGNAL>SMC_LID</SIGNAL>? Tried to adjust brightness under macOS?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Missing <SIGNAL>BKL_PWM</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Swapped DC-in, no difference. Actually... haven't tried adjusting under macOS, but assumed (perhaps foolishly) that the PRAM reset would auto-max the backlight. I'll boot into an OS and try that.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Missing <SIGNAL>BKL_PWM</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Still confirm <SIGNAL>SMC_LID</SIGNAL> is ok, the DC-in board isn't the only reason it can be bad.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Missing <SIGNAL>BKL_PWM</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>SMC_LID</SIGNAL> should be OK, as you get image.

Could be bad <CHIP>U7701</CHIP>, but try first forcing <SIGNAL>BKL_PWM</SIGNAL>.
Remove <RESISTOR>R7704</RESISTOR> and tie together <SIGNAL>BKL_EN</SIGNAL>/PWM.
If still 8.6V at backlight output, then change <CHIP>U7701</CHIP>.

Also be sure all return resistors are good.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Missing <SIGNAL>BKL_PWM</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>SMC_LID</SIGNAL> is normal and working, return resistors all seem good too.

Joining EN and PWM still results in no backlight. I've ordered some replacement drivers, hopefully have them for Monday.

Thanks both!
